results.title: 1990s Australian TV miniature
results.credit_line: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun
results.brief_description: This gorgeous miniature TV model celebrates the evolving living rooms of Australians and beloved TV from the 1990s.

constellations_primary.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_primary.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

results.description: Skippy had stiff competition for the title of Australia’s most beloved (and fictional) marsupial when Blinky Bill debuted in 1993. Based on Dorothy Wall’s books, the animated series incorporated environmental messages into its storylines and saw film and video game spin-offs. The analysis of Australian politics got satirical with Frontline, as local TV began to stretch the possibilities of what it could do creatively. While Home & Away was finding mainstream success, teenage soap Heartbreak High premiered in 1994 and tackled heady subjects for the time including racism, homelessness, drug addiction and sexuality. Crucially, it also introduced the phrase “rack off” into the pop-cultural lexicon.
description_for_label: Skippy had stiff competition for the title of Australia’s most beloved (and fictional) marsupial when Blinky Bill debuted in 1993. Based on Dorothy Wall’s books, the animated series incorporated environmental messages into its storylines and saw film and video game spin-offs. The analysis of Australian politics got satirical with Frontline, as local TV began to stretch the possibilities of what it could do creatively. While Home & Away was finding mainstream success, teenage soap Heartbreak High premiered in 1994 and tackled heady subjects for the time including racism, homelessness, drug addiction and sexuality. Crucially, it also introduced the phrase “rack off” into the pop-cultural lexicon.

results.title: 1980s Australian TV miniature
results.credit_line: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun
results.brief_description: This gorgeous miniature model celebrates the evolving design of rooms where Australians watch TV, as well as the most memorable shows from the 1980s.

constellations_primary.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_primary.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

results.description: Neighbours, everybody needs good neighbours. But it didn’t start out that way, with the now iconic Australian soap first debuting to low ratings on Channel 7 in 1985. Following its cancellation, Channel 10 snapped up the rights and took a more a youthful approach with new cast members Jason Donovan, Guy Pearce and Kylie Minogue. Neighbours creator Reg Watson had another hit with Sons and Daughters, which was modelled off prime-time soaps in the US. One of Australia’s first reality programs, Perfect Match, also debuted in 1984, featuring dating-show robot Dexter who mathematically matched contestants with a compatibility score.
description_for_label: Neighbours, everybody needs good neighbours. But it didn’t start out that way, with the now iconic Australian soap first debuting to low ratings on Channel 7 in 1985. Following its cancellation, Channel 10 snapped up the rights and took a more a youthful approach with new cast members Jason Donovan, Guy Pearce and Kylie Minogue. Neighbours creator Reg Watson had another hit with Sons and Daughters, which was modelled off prime-time soaps in the US. One of Australia’s first reality programs, Perfect Match, also debuted in 1984, featuring dating-show robot Dexter who mathematically matched contestants with a compatibility score.

results.title: 1970s Australian TV miniature
results.credit_line: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun
results.brief_description: This gorgeous model miniature celebrates the screen stories Australians loved during the 1970s.

constellations_primary.name: 1970s TV
constellations_primary.description: The 1970s was a thrilling time in Australian television as productions expanded in scale, scope, and ambition.

results.description: David Bowie. Madonna. ABBA. Kylie Minogue. If you were a music act in the 1970s, there was one show you had to be on to solidify your status and that was Countdown. Hosted by Ian ‘Molly’ Meldrum, the ABC program became an institution during its 13-year run. It was the shining jewel in the crown of Australian TV, which moved to exciting new places in the 70s with the arrival of colour. Channel 10 had the saucy Number 96, comedy found new footing with The Aunty Jack Show and the Special Broadcast Service (SBS) was officially launched in 1979 with the aim of telling multicultural Australian stories.
description_for_label: David Bowie. Madonna. ABBA. Kylie Minogue. If you were a music act in the 1970s, there was one show you had to be on to solidify your status and that was Countdown. Hosted by Ian ‘Molly’ Meldrum, the ABC program became an institution during its 13-year run. It was the shining jewel in the crown of Australian TV, which moved to exciting new places in the 70s with the arrival of colour. Channel 10 had the saucy Number 96, comedy found new footing with The Aunty Jack Show and the Special Broadcast Service (SBS) was officially launched in 1979 with the aim of telling multicultural Australian stories.

results.title: 1960s Australian TV miniature
results.credit_line: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun
results.brief_description: This gorgeous model miniature celebrates the screen stories Australians loved during the 1960s.

constellations_primary.name: 1960s television
constellations_primary.description: After its debut in the fifties, Australians rapidly became enthusiastic television viewers in the sixties as American imports started to be mixed with notable local productions.

results.description: The 60s might have been the first full decade of Australian television, but there was a surprising lack of it on the small screen as the local industry began to establish itself. In lieu of the necessary infrastructure, shows from the US dominated due to the low-cost of syndication. This all changed with requirements that commercial TV stations begin broadcasting forty per cent Australian content, which led to the first homegrown drama Consider Your Verdict in 1961. The one-hour program ran for 160 episodes on Channel 7 and ushered in a wave of other seminal Aussie shows like Four Corners and Skippy The Bush Kangaroo.
description_for_label: The 60s might have been the first full decade of Australian television, but there was a surprising lack of it on the small screen as the local industry began to establish itself. In lieu of the necessary infrastructure, shows from the US dominated due to the low-cost of syndication. This all changed with requirements that commercial TV stations begin broadcasting forty per cent Australian content, which led to the first homegrown drama Consider Your Verdict in 1961. The one-hour program ran for 160 episodes on Channel 7 and ushered in a wave of other seminal Aussie shows like Four Corners and Skippy The Bush Kangaroo.

results.title: 1950s Australian TV miniature
results.credit_line: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun
results.brief_description: This gorgeous miniature model celebrates the evolving design of rooms we watch TV in and the birth of TV in Australia.

constellations_primary.name: 1950s television
constellations_primary.description: "Good evening ... and welcome to television." Bruce Gyngell’s famous words launched television in Australia in 1956 on Sydney’s TCN9, with the medium finally arriving in the country towards the later end of the decade.

results.description: “Good evening … and welcome to television.” Those were the famous words of television pioneer Bruce Gyngell that first launched television in Australia in 1956 on Sydney’s TCN9. Experimental transmissions had been taking place as early as 1929. Yet the delay in broadcasting came from heated public debate over what kind of television the nation would have: government-run, like Britain, or commercial, like the US. The result was a uniquely combined service, utilising elements of both. The medium reached the masses just in time for the Melbourne Summer Olympic Games in September.
description_for_label: “Good evening … and welcome to television.” Those were the famous words of television pioneer Bruce Gyngell that first launched television in Australia in 1956 on Sydney’s TCN9. Experimental transmissions had been taking place as early as 1929. Yet the delay in broadcasting came from heated public debate over what kind of television the nation would have: government-run, like Britain, or commercial, like the US. The result was a uniquely combined service, utilising elements of both. The medium reached the masses just in time for the Melbourne Summer Olympic Games in September.
